title: 114_s1109
content: The "Truth in Settlements Act of 2015" requires federal agencies to provide information on settlement agreements. The "Truth in Settlements Act of 2015" mandates that federal agencies disclose details of settlement agreements, including those involving alleged violations of federal laws requiring payments of at least $1,000,000 by non-federal entities. The term 'entity within the Federal Government' includes an officer or employee of the Federal Government and pertains to settlement agreements related to federal laws requiring payments of at least $200,000 in attorney fees, costs, or expenses. The term 'non-Federal person' refers to individuals outside the Federal Government, and 'rule making' is defined as per section 551(5). Executive agencies are required to publicly disclose information online in a searchable format. The term 'rule making' is defined under section 551(5). Executive agencies must publicly post a searchable list of covered settlement agreements on their website, including the date and names of the parties involved. The covered settlement agreements must include the date, names of parties, description of claims, and payment obligations for each party involved. The covered settlement agreement specifies the amount each party is obligated to pay, the total amount all parties must pay, and the individual payment obligations for each settling party. The covered settlement agreement specifies the amount each party is obligated to pay, including any civil or criminal penalties, fines, and non-deductible amounts under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The covered settlement agreement includes non-deductible amounts under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 and specifies where collected amounts will be deposited, potentially for use by Federal Government programs. Additionally, it requires the Executive agency to provide a copy of each covered settlement agreement. The Executive agency must disclose information on settlement agreements not subject to confidentiality provisions for use by Federal Government programs. The head of each Executive agency must ensure that information on settlement agreements without confidentiality provisions is publicly available for at least 5 years, and a copy of the agreement is available for at least 1 year. The head of an Executive agency must ensure that settlement agreements with confidentiality provisions are publicly available for a specified period to protect the public interest of the United States. The head of an Executive agency must issue a public statement explaining the need for confidentiality provisions in settlement agreements to protect the public interest of the United States. This statement should outline the interests confidentiality protects and why they outweigh the public's interest in knowing about government conduct and expenditure of resources. The head of an Executive agency must issue a public statement outlining the requirements for written public statements in settlement agreements involving non-Federal persons. This includes specifying portions of payments as penalties for violations of Federal law or non-deductible under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The head of an Executive agency must issue a public statement outlining requirements for settlement agreements with non-Federal persons. This includes specifying penalties for violations of Federal law or non-deductible amounts under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The agreement must detail actions the non-Federal person will take instead of payment and any compensation involved. The head of an Executive agency must issue requirements for settlement agreements with non-Federal persons, including penalties for violations of Federal law. The agreement must detail actions the non-Federal person will take instead of payment and any compensation involved. Disclosure of information is required unless subject to a confidentiality provision. Reporting is mandated by January 15 of each year. The head of an Executive agency must report on covered settlement agreements annually to Congress by January 15, detailing the number of agreements entered into during the fiscal year. The Executive agency must report annually to Congress on covered settlement agreements, including the number of agreements entered into, the confidentiality of terms, and the total amount paid to non-Federal persons for attorney fees and expenses. The Executive agency must report annually to Congress on covered settlement agreements, including the confidentiality of terms, total amount paid to non-Federal persons for attorney fees, and the number of agreements involving regulatory action or changes. The report must be made publicly available in a searchable format. The Executive agency must report annually to Congress on covered settlement agreements, including details on regulatory changes. The report must be publicly available in a searchable format on the agency's website. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to Congress on how Executive agencies determine the confidentiality of settlement agreements within 6 months of the Act's enactment. The report will include recommendations for increasing transparency while protecting legitimate interests.
